page.title: 08WARMINSTER'S ARMY WORKSHOPS
page.content: The biggest single local employer is "the REME" (Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers 27 District Workshop), with about 440 civilian and 70 military staff, most of whom live in the Warminster/Westbury area. The workshop complex, covering a 1 km by .25 km site, was originally built in 1939, and used in the War by the Royal Army Ordnance Corps, as well as the US Army, before the REME took over in 1945. About 50 jobs are completed by the workforce each day, mainly repairs, ranging from simpler work on local army equipment, through more complex engine changes on a variety of vehicles, to full tank overhauls. All skilled trades have to serve a full apprenticeship. 22 apprentices of different types can be trained at one time, which means 5 trainees can be taken on each year.
